thread.title: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 3 tip sheet
thread.title_full: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 3 tip sheet | Toronto Star

author: Brendan Kennedy
title: Blue Jays-Royals ALCS Game 3 tip sheet
text:
The Blue Jays once again turn to Marcus Stroman in a big moment, trying to climb back into their league championship series against the Royals after dropping the first two games in Kansas City.
Only one team in Major League Baseball has ever come back from a three-game deficit.
The Royals, meanwhile, are looking to keep the Jays right where they are, sending to the mound their deadline-acquired ace, Johnny Cueto, who saved their season by pitching a gem in their division-series finale against the Houston Astros.
Here’s what you need to know about today’s game.
TORONTO BLUE JAYS vs. KANSAS CITY ROYALS
ALCS Game 3
Rogers Centre
First pitch : 8:07 p.m. ET
Roof status : Not officially announced yet, but with game-time temperatures around 13C (feeling closer to 10C), expect it to be closed as it was in all three games of the ALDS.
Starting pitchers: RHP Marcus Stroman (4-0, 1.67) vs RHP Johnny Cueto (11-13, 3.44)
TV: Fox Sports-1, simulcast in Canada on Sportsnet.
-
Projected lineups:
Blue Jays:
Ben Revere – LF
Josh Donaldson – 3B
Jose Bautista – RF
Edwin Encarnacion – DH
Chris Colabello – 1B
Troy Tulowitzki – SS
Russell Martin – C
Ryan Goins – 2B
Kevin Pillar – CF
-
Royals:
Alcides Escobar – SS
Ben Zobrist – 2B
Lorenzo Cain – CF
Eric Hosmer – 1B
Kendrys Morales – DH
Mike Moustakas – 3B
Sal Perez – C
Alex Gordon – LF
Alex Rios – RF
-
Dome sweet dome
After scoring just three runs — and hitting no homers — in two games at the expansive Kauffman Stadium in Kansas City, the Blue Jays are hoping a little home-cooking can revive their offence. Fly balls should carry a lot further under the climate-controlled closed dome than they did in the chilly Kansas City air. The Rogers Centre averaged 2.51 home runs per game this season, third-most in the league, while Kauffman Stadium averaged the fewest at 1.6 per game. Of all the home-field advantages, this is the biggest for the Jays, whose offence is built around the long ball.
Cain is able
Lorenzo Cain, the Royals’ centre-fielder who won the ALCS MVP last year, is on an 11-game post-season hit streak, dating back to last year’s World Series. Cain’s seven hits this post-season are one back of Ben Zobrist for the Royals’ lead. Blue Jays’ first baseman Chris Colabello and centre-fielder Kevin Pillar are tied with Royals’ shortstop Alcides Escobar for the AL lead with nine playoff hits.
Devo back in town
Devon White, the former Jays’ centre-fielder who played in Toronto from 1991-95, will throw out the ceremonial first pitch tonight. The speedy lead-off hitter ignited the Jays’ WAMCO (White-Alomar-Molitor-Carter-Olerud) offence during the World Series glory years and was one of the greatest defensive outfielders in franchise history. He ranks ninth among all-time Blue Jays in Wins Above Replacement, according to Fangraphs.
-
PLAYERS TO WATCH
Edwin Encarnacion: The Blue Jays’ designated hitter has only faced Cueto seven times in his career, but he has two singles, a double and a home run.
Eric Hosmer: The Royals’ first baseman has six hits this post-season and all of them have driven in runs.
